page.syntax: Result as C = UI_POPUP_MENU(C menu_format[,C code])

argument.name: Result
argument.description: The user's selection from the popup menu.

argument.name: menu_format
argument.description: A CR-LF delimited list of menu entries.

argument.name: code
argument.description: Xbasic code that responds to menu selections by examining the value of a_command. The code should be bracketed by and %code%.

page.description: Displays a Popup menu based on passed in menu format - can also augment active top level menu.
page.discussion: The UI_POPUP_MENU() displays a menu and returns the user's selection in both Result and a_command. Limitations: Desktop applications only.

section.title: Evaluating the User's Selection
section.description: Whether from a menu bar, icon bar, button, or hot spot, the UI_POPUP_MENU() function will display a multi-level drop down menu. The UI_POPUP_MENU() function is an easy and flexible method to create your own menus with all the richness of a professional looking menu with icon and conditional capabilities. By default, the function positions the menu at the cursor location. So putting the UI_POPUP_MENU() function on a button's onPush event will position the menu at the button. To begin exploring the UI_POPUP_MENU() function, put the following code on the onPush event of a button placed on a form:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One Choice Two Choice Three %a% ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: The variable, vMenuItems, is a CR-LF delimited string that contains the menu choices displayed by the UI_POPUP_MENU() function. The above code produces the following drop down menu:

Normally, you would want to respond to the user's selection, but the above code does not do this. You can respond to the user's selection either inside or outside the UI_POPUP_MENU() function. The following syntax demonstrates handling the users selection within UI_POPUP_MENU() function:
section.example: ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems,<<%code% if a_command = "Choice One" ui_msg_box("The User Selected:",a_command) else ui_msg_box("Choice One NOT Selected!","The user did not select Choice One") end if %code%)

section.description: The a_command variable is internal to Alpha Five and holds the user's selection. Checking the value of a_command will reveal the selection, and allow you to process it. For menus with many choices, you may want to process the user's selection outside of the UI_POPUP_MENU() function. It really makes no difference, but it may make the code slightly more readable. The a_command variable is not available outside of the UI_POPUP_MENU() function. Instead, you evaluate the return value (in this case vPopupReturn ) of the UI_POPUP_MENU() function.
section.example: vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems) if vPopupReturn = "Choice One" ui_msg_box("The User Selected:",vPopupReturn) else ui_msg_box("Choice One NOT Selected!","The user did not select Choice One") end if

section.title: Cascading Drop Down Menus
section.description: Assume you want two sub-selections to be available to the user if they select "Choice One". The following code does this:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One | sub-selection One Choice One | sub-selection Two Choice Two Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:

The pipe symbol, "|" on the keyboard (above the backslash), defines the break between the first and second level menu items. You can continue to create lower level cascading menu selections as the following demonstrates:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One | sub-selection One Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection two Choice Two Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:
If you want to separate Choice One from the other two choices, place "{sp}" on its own line:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One | sub-selection One Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection two {sp} Choice Two Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:
You can further separate Choice One by creating a line in the menu using the '-' command, as in the following:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One | sub-selection One Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection two - Choice Two Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:
The UI_POPUP_MENU() function automatically expands horizontally to accommodate the length of the menu, but if you want to force a larger horizontal size, you can use the "{tab}" command as in:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% Choice One | sub-selection One Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one Choice One | sub-selection Two | - Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection two - Choice Two {tab} Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:

section.title: Adding Graphics
section.description: Alpha Anywhere contains a rich selection of icons built into the program that are available for your use. To see the internal icons, type the following command in the Interactive Window :
The following example uses the hammer icon by placing the command "{I=$a5_hammer}" before each line of "Choice One".
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection One {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | - {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection two - Choice Two {tab} Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:

section.title: Evaluation Issues
section.description: The commands to add icons, and other commands such as {tab}, affect the return value of the UI_POPUP_MENU() function. In the preceding code, if the user selects "third level selection two", the a_command or the vPopupReturn variables would contain:

If you prefer a more explicit return value, you can specifically define the return value of a selection by using the ""{data=}" command. Assume you want a value of "Shut Down" returned if the user selects the "third level selection two" choice. Using the command, "{data=Shut Down}" in the following code does this:
section.example: vMenuItems = <<%a% {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection One {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | - {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | {DATA=Shut Down}{I=$a5_halt}third level selection two - Choice Two {tab} Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: Be sure not to precede the "{DATA=}" command with a space, or it will not work. This code displays the following menu:

section.title: Enabling and Disabling Menu Entries
section.description: You can conditionally enable or disable any of the menu choices with the "{enable=}" command. The logical variable vFlag demonstrates this. In the following code vFlag is set to false (.f.) value. The command "{enable=vFlag}" is immediately in front of "Choice Two".
section.example: dim vFlag as L vFlag = .F. vMenuItems = <<%a% {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection One {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | - {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | {DATA=Shut Down}{I=$a5_halt}third level selection two - {ENABLE=vFlag}Choice Two {tab} Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)

section.description: This code displays the following menu:
As you can see, "Choice Two" is now disabled and grayed out. Setting the vFlag variable to a true value (.t.) enables "Choice Two".

section.title: Positioning the Menu
section.description: One last command I want to point out is the "{position}" command. By default, Alpha Anywhere brings up your menu where ever the cursor is located. By using the "{position=x,y}" command , where x is the horizontal axis and y the vertical axis (in inches), you can set where the menu is displayed. You can also use the constant, "mouse", to use the current mouse position to replace either the x or y axis. The following example positions the menu down 2 inches, but directly below the cursor location.
section.example: dim vFlag as L vFlag = .F. vMenuItems = <<%a% {POSITION=mouse,2}{I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection One {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | third level selection one {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | - {I=$a5_hammer}Choice One | sub-selection Two | {DATA=Shut Down}{I=$a5_halt}third level selection two - {ENABLE=vFlag}Choice Two {tab} Choice Three %a% vPopupReturn = ui_popup_menu(vMenuItems)
